Room-temperature synthesis of primary amines by selective hydrogenation of nitriles over ZnAlOx supported Ni catalysts Huanyu Zhao a Yurong He a Xiaochen Wang b Jie He a ⁎ Anqiu Liu b ⁎ Zehui Zhang a a Key Laboratory of Catalysis and Energy Materials Chemistry of Ministry of Education & Hubei Key Laboratory of Catalysis and Materials Science, South-Central Minzu University, Wuhan 430074, China Key Laboratory of Catalysis and Energy Materials Chemistry of Ministry of Education & Hubei Key Laboratory of Catalysis and Materials Science, South-Central Minzu University Wuhan 430074 China Key Laboratory of Catalysis and Energy Materials Chemistry of Ministry of Education & Hubei Key Laboratory of Catalysis and Materials Science, South-Central Minzu University, Wuhan 430074, China. b School of Energy Materials & Chemical Engineering, Hefei University, Hefei 230601, Anhui, China School of Energy Materials & Chemical Engineering, Hefei University Hefei Anhui 230601 China School of Energy Materials & Chemical Engineering, Hefei University, Hefei 230601, Anhui Province, China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. Selective hydrogenation of nitriles is a feasible route to synthesize primary amines. While highly desirable, conducting the synthesis under mild conditions is challenging. We report non-precious zinc and aluminum oxides supported Ni catalysts (Ni/ZnAlOx) facilely prepared by calcination and reduction of NiZnAl layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors. The optimized Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst demonstrates great activity towards the selective hydrogenation of nitriles to primary amines. Proper-size metallic nickel provides the hydrogenation centers, and the presence of Ni-Zn alloys indicates strong metal-support interactions, which can produce electron-deficient nickel species and enhances the chemisorption of the CN bonds on the catalyst surface. The introduction of Zinc provides strong Lewis acid sites which also contribute to the catalytic activity. Based on the catalyst characterizations and control experiments, a plausible mechanism is proposed. This catalyst shows good stability and is conducive to the transformation of a variety of aromatic and aliphatic substrates, demonstrating potential application prospects. Graphical Abstract A nickel-based catalyst supported on composite metal oxides was prepared and applied to the selective reduction of nitriles to primary amines at room temperature. ga1 Keywords Primary amines Hydrogenation Non-precious catalysts Room temperature NiZnAl layered double hydroxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Primary amines are essential raw materials for the industrial synthesis of polymers, dyes, agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and aqua-chemicals [1–3]. Currently, there are many synthetic methods for primary amines, such as the hydrogenation of nitro compounds, the hydrogenation of nitriles, and the reductive amination of aldehydes [4–13]. Among them, catalytic hydrogenation of nitriles with H2 is one of the generally implemented, environmental-friendly, and atom-economic routes. Homogeneous catalysts such as Ir, Ru, Rh, Co, Mn, and Fe can catalyze the hydrogenation of nitriles [14–20]. They generally show good catalytic activity but pose challenges for catalyst re-usability and product purification, as the leaking of metal species is hardly avoided. Heterogeneous catalytic systems are generally preferred to conduct the synthesis in industry. Some precious metal catalysts such as Pd-CuFe [21], PdCu [22], and NiPd [23] were developed for the hydrogenation of nitriles to primary amines, but the high cost, as well as the low abundance of precious metal catalysts, limits their industrialization. Although there have been many reported catalytic systems for the hydrogenation of nitriles ( Scheme 1), high reaction temperature and high H2 pressure are usually needed [24–33]. Based on the above discussion, while widely applied, the selective hydrogenation of nitriles to primary amines under mild conditions even room temperature, remains a challenge, due to the hydrogenation occurring too slowly at room temperature and the selectivity of primary is not satisfactory. Therefore, it is necessary to develop non-precious catalysts with high activity and selectivity that work feasibly under mild conditions. Given the excellent hydrogenation performance of nickel [8,34–40], we believe that developing effective and selective nickel-based catalysts is of great practical and scientific significance. Herein, ZnAlOx supported Ni catalysts are reported to achieve highly selective hydrogenation of nitriles to primary amines at room temperature. The excellent performance of the optimized Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst is comparable to most reported heterogeneous systems. In addition, the relationship between the performance and catalyst structure as well as the catalytic mechanism is also investigated. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Benzonitrile was purchased from TCI Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Solvents were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Urea, Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, and all other chemicals were purchased from Aladdin Chemicals Co., Ltd (Beijing, China). All the reagents were used directly without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of NiZnAl-LDH 1.4 g of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, 4.0 g of Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, 4.5 g of Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O, and 4.5 g of urea were dissolved in 100 mL of distilled water. After vigorously stirring at 30 °C for 4 h, the clear green solution was poured into a 150 mL hydrothermal kettle, and then sealed and kept at 100 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solid was obtained by suction filtration under reduced pressure, rinsed with distilled water, and dried under vacuum at 70 °C. The product was labeled as NiZnAl-LDH. 2.3 Preparation of Ni/ZnAlOx catalysts First, the NiZnAl-LDH was calcinated at 600 °C in the air for 2 h to generate metal oxide (NiZnAlOx), which was then treated at 500–650 °C in a reduction atmosphere flow (Ar: H2 = 9:1, v/v) for 2 h with a ramp rate of 5 °C/min and a gas velocity of 40 mL/min. After cooling to 25 °C in the reductive atmosphere, black powder was obtained and recorded as Ni/ZnAlOx-T (T represents the reduction temperature). For comparison, the catalyst that was not reduced under a reduction atmosphere was named Ni/ZnAlOx-air. Ni/Al2O3-600: The Ni/Al2O3-600 catalyst was prepared following a similar preparation procedure of Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst except without the addition of Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O. Ni/ZnO-600: The Ni/ZnO-600 catalyst was prepared following a similar preparation procedure of Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst except without the addition of Al(NO3)3·9 H2O. ZnAlOx-600: The ZnAlOx-600 catalyst was prepared following a similar preparation procedure of Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst except without the addition of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O. 2.4 Characterization of catalysts The content of Ni in the Ni/ZnAlOx-T catalysts was analyzed using an inductively coupled atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) on the IRIS Intrepid II XSP instrument (Thermo Electron Corporation). The morphologies of the catalysts were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI TECNAI G2–20). X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) experiments were conducted on a Bruker D8 Advance powder diffractometer (Cu Kα) with a rate of 0.016°/s scanning in the 2θ scope of 10–80°. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption were performed to measure the physical properties of the Ni/ZnAlOx-T catalysts on a V-Sorb 2800 P instrument at 77 K. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB Xi+ spectrometer with a monochromatized Al Kα source (1486.6 eV) at constant analyzer pass energy of 25 eV. Temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) test and temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) were conducted on the Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 instrument. The nature and strength of surface acid sites were determined by BRUKER VERTEX 70 FT-IR spectrometer using pyridine as a probe molecule (Py-IR). 2.5 Catalyst activity test The hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a 40 mL stainless steel lined high-pressure reactor. In a representative operation, 0.5 mmol of benzonitrile, 20 mg of catalyst, and 10 mL of solvent were placed in the autoclave. After scavenging the impurity gas in the reactor through multiple exchanges with H2, 10 bar H2 was finally charged into the autoclave. And then the reaction was performed for 4 h at room temperature with magnetic stirring of 1000 rpm. After the reaction, the reaction mixture was quantitatively analyzed with Agilent 7820 A gas chromatography (GC). 2.6 Methods for product analysis Agilent 7820 A GC equipped with a flame ionization detector and a cross-linked capillary HP-5 column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.4 mm) was used to analyze the products. N2 was used as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 40 mL/min. The injection port temperature was 300 °C. The initial temperature of the column oven is 50 °C, the heating rate is 10 °C/min, and the detector temperature is set to 300 °C. Ethylbenzene was used as an internal standard. 3 Result and discussion The schematic diagram of the preparation of Ni/ZnAlOx-T catalysts is shown in Fig. 1. The preparation includes two steps, (i) the co-precipitation of the Ni2+, Zn2+, and Al3+ precursors and (ii) the calcination and reduction process. The samples prepared under different reduction temperatures were donated as Ni/ZnAlOx-500, Ni/ZnAlOx-600, and Ni/ZnAlOx-650, respectively. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the NiZnAl-LDH, Ni/Al2O3-600, and Ni/ZnAlOx-T catalysts are shown in Fig. S1 and Fig. 2. The NiZnAl-LDH sample shows the characteristic diffraction peaks at 11.8°, 23.7°, 34.7°, 39.5°, 47.2°, 53.4°, 57.0°, 60.5°, and 61.8°, which are indexed to LDH phase (PDF#52–1082) [41]. The characteristic diffraction peaks at 44.3°, 51.7°, and 76.2° are indexed to the metallic Ni phase (PDF#89–7128), as shown in the XRD pattern of the Ni/Al2O3-600 sample (Fig. S1). As shown in Fig. 2, diffraction peaks at 31.7°, 34.3°, 36.2°, 47.5°, 56.5°, 62.9°, 67.8° and 69.2° are attributed to the ZnO phase (PDF#36–1451), and the peaks at 36.8°, 55.6°, and 59.4° are ascribed to ZnAl2O4 (PDF#05–0669). Both ZnO and ZnAl2O4 phases exist in all of the as-prepared catalysts, indicating that the reduction treatment does not change the basic structure of the supports. The peaks of NiO (PDF#89–7390) at 37.2° and 62.9° are covered by ZnO (PDF#36–1451), and the characteristic peak at 43.3° can be ascribed to NiO. Through hydrogen reduction treatment, nickel species changed from oxidized nickel into metallic nickel, and the peak intensity of Ni became stronger with the rise of the reduction temperature. It is worth noting that the metallic Ni peaks at 43.2°, 51.7°, and 76.1° slightly shift to the small angle, revealing possible lattice expansions of Ni0. As the atomic radius of Zn is larger than Ni, the slight shift may be explained by the possible alloying between Ni and Zn during the calcination and reduction process. In general, it is difficult to reduce Zn2+ species to metallic Zn with H2, and this reduction occurs in Ni/ZnAlOx-600 and Ni/ZnAlOx-650 catalysts may be due to close contact between the metallic Ni and the zinc-containing support [42]. Hydrogen is adsorbed on the metallic Ni by dissociation to form hydrogen atoms, which overflow to reduce the adjacent Zn species [42]. The ICP results reveal that the Ni content in the Ni/ZnAlOx-500, Ni/ZnAlOx-600, and Ni/ZnAlOx-650 catalysts is 5.4 wt%, 7.4 wt%, and 7.5 wt%, respectively (Table S1). The difference in Ni content is also attributed to a higher reduction degree of nickel oxides at higher reduction temperatures. As shown in Fig. S2, the NiZnAl-LDH precursor exhibits a hierarchical petal-like morphology before and after the calcination and reduction process. As shown in Fig. 3, the metallic Ni nano-particles can be distinctly found in the TEM image of the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst. They are homogeneously distributed without serious aggregation, and the average grain diameter of Ni nano-particles is 8.5 nm, which is larger than some of the previously reported ones [34,35,40,43], because of the possible formation of Ni-Zn alloy during the catalyst preparation [42,44]. The fringe spacing distance of 0.206 nm, 0.243 nm, 0.283 nm, 0.209 nm, and 0.241 nm measured in the high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) image of Ni/ZnAlOx-600, correspond to the (111) plane of metallic Ni, (311) plane of ZnAl2O4, (100) plane of ZnO, (101) plane of metallic Ni-Zn and (101) plane of metallic NiO, respectively. As shown in Fig. S2, higher reduction temperature results in the growth of the nano-particles, and the average size of the nano-particles in the Ni/ZnAlOx-650 sample is around 17.3 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to probe the different chemical valence states of the elements on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. 4, two peaks were fitted for the Ni species. The binding energy values at 852.2–852.4 eV and 869.3–869.7 eV may be assigned to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of metallic Ni0, respectively, while the binding energy values at 855.5–855.7 eV (Ni2+ 2p3/2) and 873.2–873.5 eV (Ni2+ 2p1/2) indicate the presence of nickel oxide. The peaks located between 861.5 and 861.6 eV and 879.5–880.0 eV can be attributed to the satellite peak of Ni2+ (Table S2). The presence of Ni oxide in the catalyst might be partially caused by the slight oxidation during placement in the air. Compared with the Ni/Al2O3-600 catalyst, Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst shows slightly higher Ni 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 binding energy (Ni/ZnAlOx-600 vs Ni/Al2O3-600, 852.3 and 869.4 eV vs 852.2 and 869.3 eV, respectively), revealing a possible charge transfer from the Ni atoms to the Zn atoms, which further confirms the formation of Ni-Zn alloy on the catalyst. The Ni/ZnAlOx-650 catalyst also shows this property (Ni/ZnAlOx-650 vs Ni/Al2O3-600, 852.4 and 869.7 eV vs 852.2 and 869.3 eV, respectively). This phenomenon has been verified by similar observations in literature [45–47]. This strong charge transfer between nickel and ZnAl support may produce electron-deficient Ni species, thus enhancing the chemisorption for CN bonds in nitrile molecules. The increase in the proportion of Ni0 and Ni2+ species also enhanced the reduction degree of Ni with the increase in calcination temperature. The Ni/ZnAlOx-500 sample shows no metallic Ni because only a small amount or almost no NiO in the precursor was reduced to Ni0 at 500 °C, which is consistent with the XRD result. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the NiZnAl-LDH and the Ni/ZnAlOx-T catalysts exhibit typical IV-type isotherm curves in the P/P0 scope of 0.4–0.9, which is the characteristic of mesoporous structure (Fig. S3 and Fig. 5). As shown in Table S3, the prepared NiZnAl-LDH and Ni/ZnAlOx-500 catalysts show BET surface area of 115.2 m2/g and 95.0 m2/g, and pore size of 16.1 nm and 18.6 nm, respectively. With the increasing reduction temperature, the BET surface area decreased to 63.5 m2/g for the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 and 39.4 m2/g for Ni/ZnAlOx-650 respectively, which may be due to the collapse of hierarchical structure, as compared to Ni/ZnAlOx-500 catalyst. Moreover, the reduction behaviors of catalysts were tested through H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). As illustrated in Fig. 6a, Ni/ZnAlOx-500 shows a wide and strong peak with the center around 650 °C, due to the reduction of bulk NiO in the NiZnAl mixed oxides, which further confirms the above statements that NiO in the Ni/ZnAlOx-500 is hardly reduced to metallic Ni nano-particles. The intensity of the reduction peak decreases sharply or even almost disappears at around 650 °C, suggesting that the NiO phase in the mixed metal oxide precursor is nearly completely reduced to metallic Ni nano-particles by H2 with a reduction temperature beyond 600 °C. However, a weak reduction peak between 100 and 200 °C is intuitively noticed in the H2-TPR profiles of the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 and Ni/ZnAlOx-650 catalysts, which is due to the reduction of oxides formed by slight oxidation of nickel nano-particles during placement in the air. The acidic properties of the catalysts were studied by NH3-TPD (Fig. 6b). All catalysts show a weak peak around 200 °C, corresponding to a weak acidic site, which may be related to the Al3+ species. The catalysts (Ni/Al2O3-600) without Zn species show an NH3 desorption peak around 400 °C, corresponding to the medium-strength acidic sites. For the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst, the NH3 desorption peak at around 650 °C corresponds to the strong acidic sites. These results indicated that the addition of Zn species increased the acidic site of the catalyst [48]. The surface structure and acid-base association of the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst were investigated by the analysis of pyridine adsorption by RT and desorption at 25, 150, and 300 °C by FT-IR spectra (Fig. 6c). The pyridine ligated on Lewis acid site (L) shows characteristic absorption bands at 1455 and 1616 cm−1, the pyridine adsorbed on Brønsted acid site (B) observes characteristic absorption bands at 1540 and 1652 cm−1, 1490 cm−1 ascribes to pyridine adsorbed onto both Lewis and Brønsted acid site (B+L). More importantly, the results of Table S4 showed that the L/B ratio increased with the increase in desorption temperature, indicating that the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst possesses a strong Lewis acidity [43]. XPS revealed that the existence of strong electron interactions between metallic nickel and ZnAl support can produce electron-deficient Ni species. Therefore, although the Ni/Al2O3-600 catalyst (without Zn) can promote the conversion of benzonitrile, the selectivity for benzylamine was not high. In contrast, the introduction of zinc species enabled Lewis acid produced by zinc species on the surface of nickel nano-particles to act as an electron acceptor by adsorbing benzonitrile to fix selectively the N atoms of the CN bonds, which facilitated the functionalization of CN bonds [49,50]. The catalytic performance of the mesoporous Ni/ZnAlOx-T catalysts was judged by the reduction of benzonitrile to benzylamine as a model reaction. As shown in Table 1, no conversion and the negligible conversion of benzonitrile (Table 1, Entries 1 & 2) were observed for Ni/ZnAlOx-air and Ni/ZnAlOx-500 catalysts, respectively, which suggested that NiO could not activate the H2 molecules to promote the hydrogenation of nitriles. As expected, the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 and Ni/ZnAlOx-650 catalysts with metallic Ni and Ni-Zn alloy as the active species showed high activity for the hydrogenation of benzonitrile, which gave conversions of 57.1% and 47.1% after 4 h at room temperature (Table 1, Entries 3 & 4), respectively. The slightly higher reactivity of Ni/ZnAlOx-600 to Ni/ZnAlOx-650 was due to its smaller size of metallic Ni nano-particles, which provided more contact sites to the substrates. In addition, the main product of the selective hydrogenation reaction was benzylamine, and the selectivity of benzylamine was as high as 91.1% and 92.7% over the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 and Ni/ZnAlOx-650 catalyst, respectively. Therefore, Ni/ZnAlOx-600 showed the highest activity and selectivity in the experiments, as Ni/ZnAlOx-600 occupied higher content of metallic Ni than Ni/ZnAlOx-500 and smaller Ni particle size than Ni/ZnAlOx-650, according to the XPS and TEM characterizations. Moreover, compared with Ni/ZnAlOx-600, the conversion of benzonitrile over Ni/Al2O3-600 (without Zn) was only 43.3%, and the selectivity of benzylamine was 40.0%, indicating that the existence of Zn species greatly promoted the catalytic efficiency (Table 1, Entry 5). The catalytic activity of the Ni/ZnO catalyst was only 2.1% (Table 1, Entry 6), indicating the essential role of Al2O3 as the main support. ZnAlOx catalyst without Ni in the catalytic reaction did not show any activity (Table 1, Entry 7). Particularly, we attribute the room temperature reaction property of the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst to the introduction of zinc, which has two effects: the formation of Ni-Zn alloy and the introduction of Lewis acid. The formation of Ni-Zn alloys initiates the charge transfer from Ni to Zn, revealing strong electron interaction between Ni and Zn [45–47]. This electron interaction can produce electron-deficient nickel species, which is more favorable for the adsorption of benzonitrile as well as the dissociated adsorption of H2 by decreasing the activation energy [45,50]. This is the major reason that the reaction can be activated at room temperature. (ii) Lewis acid brought by Zn also contributes to the selective hydrogenation of benzonitrile. The Lewis acid acts as an electron acceptor and interacts with the N atom on the CN bonds in the benzonitrile adsorbed on the catalyst, making the CN bonds functionalized [49]. Therefore, the reaction could be performed at a much lower temperature. The excellent catalytic effect of the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 was also compared with representative systems [8,21–40]. The results show that the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst is comparable to most of the reported catalysts (Table S5). Having clarified the role of the catalyst components, the reaction conditions were optimized for the reduction of benzonitrile. Firstly, we investigated the influence of different solvents on catalytic hydrogenation activity ( Table 2). In contrast to previous reports on the hydrogenation of nitriles [25–27], Ni/ZnAlOx-600 had been investigated to be completely inactive in the oxygen-containing solvents with strong polarity (Table 2, entries 1–4), and the possible reason might be due to the affinity of these solvents to the catalytic sites for the presence of oxygen atoms in these solvents. Moderate to high yields were produced in hydrocarbon solvent regardless of the polarity (Table 2, entries 5–9). The best result was obtained in the hexane solvent. When 200 μL of methanol was added to hexane solvent, the conversion of benzonitrile was significantly decreased (Table 2, Entry 6 vs 10, 57.1% vs 32.5%). When the content of methanol was increased to 400 μL, the conversion of benzonitrile continued to decrease to 20.6% (Table 2, Entry 11). These results indicated that there was competitive adsorption between oxygen-containing molecules (such as methanol) and benzonitrile. Subsequently, the influence of the pressure of hydrogen and the amount of NH3·H2O was also examined for the hydrogenation of benzonitrile ( Fig. 7). With the increase of H2 pressure from 1 bar to 20 bar, the conversion of benzonitrile gradually increased from 25.0% to 63.0%, which may be attributed to the increase of the hydrogen content in the reaction system as well as the surface layer of the catalyst, promoting the hydrogenation of benzonitrile (Fig. 7a). However, the selectivity of benzylamine was not significantly affected by the hydrogen pressure, which remained around 90.0%. Besides, the loading of NH3·H2O on the hydrogenation of benzonitrile was also investigated (Fig. 7b). Without the addition of NH3·H2O, the conversion of benzonitrile was 50.5% and the selectivity of benzylamine was only 16.0%. It was obvious that the presence of NH3·H2O could not significantly promote the hydrogenation of benzonitrile. However, the selectivity of primary amine increased with the gradual rise of NH3·H2O content. When 200 μL NH3·H2O was added into the catalytic system, the selectivity of benzylamine reached more than 90.0%. To our pleasure, the formation of dibenzylamine was not observed in our catalytic system. The time curve of the yield of the hydrogenation of benzonitrile was recorded in Fig. 8. In the process of reaction, the conversion of benzonitrile was gradually increased, and the yield of benzylamine also increased gradually under normal circumstances. The content of N-benzylidene benzylamine first increased and then decreased, indicating that it can be further converted to the target product (benzylamine) as an intermediate. It gave the 99.8% conversion of benzonitrile and 99.0% yield of benzylamine after 14 h at room temperature under the 10 bar H2 pressure. Further, we applied this catalytic system to different kinds of nitriles to investigate the universality of the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst. As observed in Table 3, all reactions were performed in 10 bar H2 and within 25–80 °C to afford the moderate to excellent yields of primary amines. 4-methylbenzonitrile, 4-methoxybenzonitrile, and 2-naphthonitrile can be reduced under room temperature (25 °C) with almost quantitative yield (Table 3, substrates 1, 4, and 8), which is superior to most heterogeneous catalyst. Higher temperatures and more NH3·H2O were needed when reacting with a large steric hindrance 2-methylbenzonitrile and 3-methylbenzonitrile. (Table 3, substrates 2 and 3) which indicated that the steric hindrance of substituents showed a significant effect on the substrate activity due to the inaccessibility of the nitrile-based group with the Ni sites on the surface of the catalyst. Besides, the electronic properties of the substituent groups were also found to be influential on the hydrogenation of nitriles. Substrates with electron-giving groups (Table 3, substrates 1–4 and 13–14) showed significantly higher activity than aromatic nitriles with electron-drawing groups (Table 3, substrates 5–7 and 12), and the latter required a higher temperature, more NH3·H2O amount, and longer time to achieve the best conversion over the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst. It was worth noting that no dehalogenation reaction was found in this investigation, which may be related to the mild conditions of nonprecious-based metals catalytic systems (Table 3, substrates 5–7). It was glad that nitriles bearing N-heterocycle also represented high activity, realizing complete conversion. However, the selectivity of the corresponding primary amine was lower than benzylamine (Table 3, substrates 9–11). It might be caused by the alkaline pyridine ring in nitriles containing N-heterocycles, which promoted the hydrolysis of the cyano group to obtain amide by-products. Interestingly, when 1, 3-benzenedicarbonitrile was applied to this reaction, only 3-cyanobenzylamine was generated, the reason might be that the steric hindrance induced by meta-methylamine prevented the continued reaction (Table 3, substrate 12). In addition, aldehyde, acetyl, valeronitrile, and cyclohexyl benzonitrile (Table 3, substrates 15–18) all showed excellent activity and selectivity. The potential of the catalyst was further probed by employing the more challenging benzylic nitriles. The obtained results showed that all benzylic nitriles reacted smoothly with high to excellent yield; however, higher temperature and longer time were needed due to the lower activity of these substrates (Table 3, 19–24). Subsequently, we explored the reaction route of hydrogenation of benzonitrile to benzylamine through a series of control experiments ( Scheme 2). In the absence of NH3·H2O, the conversion of benzonitrile hardly decreased, but the selectivity of benzylamine decreased significantly. The main product was N-benzylidene benzylamine, indicating that the role of NH3·H2O was to control the selectivity of the product. However, N-benzylidene benzylamine had almost no conversion under the H2 atmosphere without NH3·H2O, which explains why there was no dibenzylamine in the catalytic system. With benzonitrile and N-benzylidene benzylamine as substrate, the conversion of benzonitrile was significantly lower than the latter (57.1% vs 88.7%) under the conditions of 200 μL NH3·H2O and 10 bar H2. Therefore, it can be concluded that the main reaction route was coupling to obtain intermediate N-benzylidene benzylamine and then further ammonolysis and hydrogenation. In other words, Path A was dominant in this reaction ( Scheme 3). Benzylamine was produced by direct hydrogenation of benzonitrile in the absence of ammonia. Benzonitrile (Compound A) was reduced by hydrogenation of one hydrogen molecule to phenylmethanimine (Compound B) and then reacted with one hydrogen molecule to form benzylamine (Compound E). The by-product N-benzylidene benzylamine (Compound C) was formed by condensation of phenylmethanimine (Compound B) and benzylamine (Compound E) to remove one molecule of ammonia. After adding ammonia, hydrogenation coupling is the main way of benzonitrile hydrogenation (Path A). Benzonitrile (Compound A) was first hydrogenated to form phenylmethanimine (Compound B). The phenylmethanimine (Compound B) and benzylamine (Compound E) condensed and released one molecule of ammonia to form N-benzylidene benzylamine (Compound C). However, the reaction of phenylmethylimide (Compound B) was a too weak response to be detected. Proper-size metallic nickel nano-particles in the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst were recognized as the hydrogenation sites, which were easy to dissociation of hydrogen. The presence of Ni-Zn alloys indicated that strong metal-support interactions can produce electron-deficient nickel species, which led to the enhancement of directional chemisorption of CN bonds in the nitrile on the nickel surface. At the same time, NiOx in Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst enhanced the adsorption of phenylmethanimine (Compound B) and benzylamine (Compound E), and the promoter condensed the two molecules into N-benzylidene benzylamine (Compound C) [51]. In addition, the introduction of zinc species enabled Lewis acid produced by zinc species on the surface of nickel nano-particles to act as an electron acceptor by adsorbing benzonitrile to fix selectively the N atoms of the CN bonds, which facilitated the functionalization of CN bonds [49,50]. In the reaction, although N-benzylidene benzylamine (Compound C) was very sensitive to hydrogenation, no dibenzylamine was formed, probably because the hydrogenation of benzonitrile to a higher reaction temperature was required. The stability of the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst was finally judged by the reduction of benzonitrile as the model reaction at 25 °C and 10 bar H2 ( Fig. 9a). At the end of each reaction, the solid matter was parted via centrifugation and the used catalyst was rinsed with deionized water, dried in vacuum and reused in the next run. In the whole process of recycling, the benzonitrile conversion and benzylamine yield showed no significant decrease, which suggested that the Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst was highly stable. The XRD pattern of the catalyst showed no significant change, indicating that the structure of the catalyst was stable before and after use (Fig. 9b). The TEM of the used catalyst and the particle size distribution of Ni nano-particles in TEM of the used catalyst did not change significantly, indicating that the catalyst had excellent stability (Fig. 9c), and the XPS spectra of Ni 2p of fresh and used Ni/ZnAlOx-600 showed little difference (Fig. 9d). The excellent stability of the catalyst may be attributed to the violent interaction between Ni metallic nano-particles and ZnAl support as well as the mild reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed an efficient method for the preparation of structure-diverse primary amines from the reduction of nitriles over the inexpensive and stable Ni/ZnAlOx-600 under mild conditions. The Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst demonstrated comparable or even higher activity than noble and most non-precious metal catalysts. Proper-size metallic nickel provides the hydrogenation centers, NiOx enhanced the adsorption of phenylmethanimine and benzylamine, the formation of Ni-Zn alloys facilitated the enhancement of directional chemisorption of CN bonds in the benzonitrile, and the introduction of Zinc into the catalyst provides strong Lewis acid sites which also contribute greatly to the room-temperature catalytic activity. Our developed methods demonstrate some obvious advantages including the facile catalyst preparation, the low catalyst cost, the mild reaction condition, the wide substrate scope, and the excellent catalyst stability. coredata.dc:description: Selective hydrogenation of nitriles is a feasible route to synthesize primary amines. While highly desirable, conducting the synthesis under mild conditions is challenging. We report non-precious zinc and aluminum oxides supported Ni catalysts (Ni/ZnAlOx) facilely prepared by calcination and reduction of NiZnAl layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors. The optimized Ni/ZnAlOx-600 catalyst demonstrates great activity towards the selective hydrogenation of nitriles to primary amines. Proper-size metallic nickel provides the hydrogenation centers, and the presence of Ni-Zn alloys indicates strong metal-support interactions, which can produce electron-deficient nickel species and enhances the chemisorption of the CN bonds on the catalyst surface. The introduction of Zinc provides strong Lewis acid sites which also contribute to the catalytic activity. Based on the catalyst characterizations and control experiments, a plausible mechanism is proposed. This catalyst shows good stability and is conducive to the transformation of a variety of aromatic and aliphatic substrates, demonstrating potential application prospects.
coredata.dc:title: Room-temperature synthesis of primary amines by selective hydrogenation of nitriles over ZnAlOx supported Ni catalysts
